data.sampled: Name: Short Put Spread. (This strategy involves selling one put option with a strike price of $88 for $1.49 and buying another put option with a strike price of $93 for $2.77, while also selling one call option with a strike price of $110 for $1.02 and buying another call option with a strike price of $105 for $2.06.)

data.sampled: Short Put Spread (with a long call). It is also known as Vertical Spread. This is because you are simultaneously buying and selling options with the same expiration date but different strike prices. The net sale price of the put options is used to offset the net purchase price of the call options. The difference in the prices of the bought and sold options would determine the profit or loss of the trade. The maximum loss in this trade is limited to the difference between the strike prices minus the net credit received.

data.sampled: This is a Bull Put Spread Option Strategy. This strategy is implemented by selling a put option with a strike price of $125 and simultaneously buying a put option with a strike price of $130, both with the same expiration date. Simultaneously, the investor is selling a call option with a strike price of $175 while also buying a call option with a strike price of $170. This strategy benefits from a moderate decline in the stock price but not from a significant decline. If the stock price remains stable, the investor can earn a net credit. This strategy is considered to be relatively less risky.
